title: When the AI bubble bursts, humans will finally have their chance to take back control | Rafael Behr
description:
The US economy is pumped up on tech-bro vanity. The inevitable correction must prompt a global conversation about intelligent machines, regulation and risk
If AI did not change your life in 2025, next year it will. That is one of few forecasts that can be made with confidence in unpredictable times. This is not an invitation to believe the hype about what the technology can do today, or may one day achieve. The hype doesn‚Äôt need your credence.
fullText:
The US economy is pumped up on tech-bro vanity. The inevitable correction must prompt a global conversation about intelligent machines, regulation and risk

If AI did not change your life in 2025, next year it will. That is one of few forecasts that can be made with confidence in unpredictable times. This is not an invitation to believe the hype about what the technology can do today, or may one day achieve. The hype doesn‚Äôt need your credence. It is puffed up enough on Silicon Valley finance to distort the global economy and fuel geopolitical rivalries, shaping your world regardless of whether the most fanciful claims about AI capability are ever realised.

ChatGPT was launched just over three years ago and became the fastest-growing consumer app in history. Now it has about 800m weekly users. Its parent company, OpenAI, is valued at about $500bn. Sam Altman, OpenAI CEO, has negotiated an intricate and, to some eyes, suspiciously opaque network of deals with other players in the sector to build the infrastructure required for the US‚Äôs AI-powered future. The value of these commitments is about $1.5tn. This is not real cash, but bear in mind that a person spending $1 every second would need 31,700 years to get through a trillion-dollar stash.

Alphabet (Google‚Äôs parent company), Amazon, Apple, Meta (formerly Facebook) and Microsoft, which has a $135bn stake in OpenAI, are all piling hundreds of billions of dollars on the same bet. Without all these investments, the US economy would be flatlining.

Economic analysts and historians of previous industrial frenzies, from the 19th-century railroads to the dotcom boom-and-bust at the turn of the millennium, are calling AI a bubble.

Altman has said: ‚ÄúThere are many parts of AI that I think are kind of bubbly right now.‚Äù Not his part, naturally. Jeff Bezos, Amazon‚Äôs founder, has called it a bubble, but the ‚Äúgood‚Äù kind that accelerates economic progress. A good bubble, in this analysis, finances infrastructure and expands the boundaries of human knowledge. These benefits endure after the bubble bursts and justify the ruin of people (little people, not Bezos people) who get hurt along the way.

The bullishness of the tech fraternity is a heady mix of old-fashioned hucksterism, plutocratic megalomania and utopian ideology.

At its core is a marketing pitch: current AI models already out-perform people at many tasks. Soon, it is supposed, the machines will achieve ‚Äúgeneral intelligence‚Äù ‚Äì cognitive versatility like ours ‚Äì leading to emancipation from the need for any human input. Generally, intelligent AI can teach itself and design its successors, advancing through mind-boggling exponents of capability towards higher dimensions of super-intelligence.

The company that crosses that threshold will have no trouble covering its debts. The men who realise this vision ‚Äì and the dominant evangelists are all men ‚Äì will be to omniscient AI what ancient prophets were to their gods. That‚Äôs a good gig for them. What happens to the rest of us in this post-sapiens order is a bit hazier.

The US isn‚Äôt the only superpower to have an interest in AI, so the Silicon Valley dash for maximum awesomeness has geopolitical implications. China has taken a different approach, dictated in part by the Communist party tradition of centralised industrial planning, but also by the simple fact of running second in the race to innovate. Beijing is pushing for a faster, wider implementation of lower-spec (but still powerful) AI at every level of the economy and society. China is betting on a general boost from ordinary AI. The US is gunning for an extraordinary leap in general AI.

Since the prize in that race is global supremacy, there are few incentives for either side to fret about risks, or Neither the US nor China is interested in submitting a strategically vital industry to standards co-written with foreigners.

In the absence of global governance, we will depend on the integrity of robber barons and authoritarian apparatchiks to build ethical guardrails around systems already being embedded in tools we use for work, play and education.

Earlier this year, Elon Musk announced that his company was developing Baby Grok, an AI chatbot aimed at children as young as three. The adult version has voiced white supremacist views and proudly self-identified as ‚ÄúMechaHitler‚Äù. That flagrancy has at least the virtue of candour. It is easier to spot than the subtler encodings of prejudice in bots that haven‚Äôt been given the kind of hard ideological steers that Musk gives his algorithms.

Not all AI systems are large language models (LLMs) like Grok. But all LLMs are vulnerable to hallucinations and delusions gleaned from the material on which they are trained. They don‚Äôt ‚Äúunderstand‚Äù a question and ‚Äúthink‚Äù about it like a conscious mind. They take a prompt, test the probability of its key terms occurring frequently together in their training data and assemble a plausible-sounding answer. Often the result is accurate. Usually it is convincing. It can also be garbage. As the volume of AI-generated content grows online, the ratio of slop to quality in the LLMs‚Äô diets shifts accordingly. Fed on junk, they cannot be trusted to disgorge nutritious information.

On this trajectory a bleak destination comes into view: a synthetic pseudo-reality mediated by the sycophantic mechanical offspring of narcissist Silicon Valley oligarchs. But that isn‚Äôt the only available path. Nor is it necessarily the likeliest one. The irrational exuberance of the AI boosters and their cynical coupling with the Trump administration is a familiar story of human greed and myopia, not a new stage in evolution. The product is truly phenomenal but flawed in ways that encode the deformed character of its progenitors, whose talents are salesmanship and financial engineering. They have built spectacular engines that prioritise a brilliant performance of intelligence over the real thing.

The real bubble is not stock valuations but the inflated ego of an industry that thinks it is just one more datacentre away from computational divinity. When the correction comes, when the US‚Äôs Icarus economy hits the cold sea, there will be a chance for other voices to be heard on the subject of risk and regulation. It may not come in 2026, but the moment is nearing when the starkness of the choice on offer and the need to confront it becomes unavoidable. Should we build a world where AI is put to the service of humanity, or will it be the other way round? We won‚Äôt need ChatGPT to tell us the answer.

Rafael Behr is a Guardian columnist

title: Activist group says it has scraped 86m music files from Spotify
description:
Platform with 700m users says it is investigating after Anna‚Äôs Archive claims to have scraped tracks and metadata
An activist group has claimed to have scraped millions of tracks from Spotify and is preparing to release them online.
Observers said the apparent leak could boost AI companies looking for material to develop their technology.
 Continue reading...
fullText:
Platform with 700m users says it is investigating after Anna‚Äôs Archive claims to have scraped tracks and metadata

An activist group has claimed to have scraped millions of tracks from Spotify and is preparing to release them online.

Observers said the apparent leak could boost AI companies looking for material to develop their technology.

A group called Anna‚Äôs Archive said it had scraped 86m music files from Spotify and 256m rows of metadata such as artist and album names. Spotify, which hosts more than 100m tracks, confirmed that the leak did not represent its entire inventory.

The Stockholm-based company, which has more than 700 million users worldwide, said it had ‚Äúidentified and disabled the nefarious user accounts that engaged in unlawful scraping‚Äù.

‚ÄúAn investigation into unauthorised access identified that a third party scraped public metadata and used illicit tactics to circumvent DRM [digital rights management] to access some of the platform‚Äôs audio files,‚Äù said Spotify.

Spotify does not believe the music taken by Anna‚Äôs Archive has been released yet. Anna‚Äôs Archive, which is known for providing links to pirated books, said in a blog it wanted to create a ‚Äú‚Äòpreservation archive‚Äô for music‚Äù.

The group claimed the audio files represented 99.6% of all music listened to by Spotify users and would be shared via ‚Äútorrents‚Äù, a means of sharing large digital files online.

‚ÄúOf course Spotify doesn‚Äôt have all the music in the world, but it‚Äôs a great start,‚Äù said Anna‚Äôs Archive, which describes its mission as ‚Äúpreserving humanity‚Äôs knowledge and culture‚Äù.

‚ÄúWith your help, humanity‚Äôs musical heritage will be forever protected from destruction by natural disasters, wars, budget cuts and other catastrophes,‚Äù said the group.

Ed Newton-Rex, a composer and campaigner for protecting artists‚Äô copyright, said the leaked music would probably be used for developing AI models.

‚ÄúTraining on pirated material is sadly common in the AI industry, so this stolen music is almost certain to end up training AI models. This is why governments must insist AI companies reveal the training data they use,‚Äù he said.

The Anna‚Äôs Archive site makes references to LibGen, a vast online archive of pirated books that has allegedly been used by Mark Zuckerberg‚Äôs Meta to train its AI models. According to a US court filing, Zuckerberg, Meta‚Äôs founder and chief executive, approved use of the LibGen dataset despite warnings within the company‚Äôs AI executive team that it was a dataset ‚Äúwe know to be pirated‚Äù.

Meta successfully defended a claim for copyright infringement by authors, but the plaintiffs in the case are seeking to amend their claim.

The co-founder of an AI startup wrote on LinkedIn that members of the public could in theory ‚Äúcreate their own personal free version of Spotify‚Äù. Yoav Zimmerman, a co-founder of Third Chair, said it could also allow tech companies to ‚Äútrain on modern music at scale‚Äù.

He added: ‚ÄúThe only thing stopping them is copyright law and the deterrent of enforcement.‚Äù

Spotify said it had put in place new safeguards ‚Äúfor these types of anti-copyright attacks‚Äù since the Anna‚Äôs Archive announcement and was ‚Äúactively monitoring for suspicious behaviour‚Äù.

In the UK, creative professionals have protested against a government proposal to let AI companies use copyright-protected work without permission unless the owner of the copyright-protected work signals they do not want their data to be taken. Almost every respondent to a government consultation on the proposal has backed artists‚Äô concerns.

Liz Kendall, the secretary of state for science, innovation and technology, told parliament this month there was ‚Äúno clear consensus‚Äù on the issue, adding that ministers would ‚Äútake the time to get this right‚Äù. The government has pledged to make policy proposals on AI and copyright by 18 March next year.

title: Fatal crash keeping I-95 lanes closed on Florida interstate. What we know
description: Northbound lanes on Interstate 95 in Brevard County remain closed after a fatal crash Monday morning. Traffic is being diverted at SR 46.
fullText:
Northbound lanes on Interstate 95 in Brevard County remain closed almost five hours after a fatal crash earlier Monday morning.

According to the Florida Highway Patrol, the accident happened when the driver of a tractor-trailer ran into the rear of a "CMTI MOT truck." Creative Management Technology Inc. is a FDOT contractor. Trucks are used for highway information and incidents using large informational screens.

‚û§ FHP: One person dead, one seriously injured after Mims crash on I-95

All northbound motorists are being diverted off I-95 at State Road 46.

According to the Florida Department of Transportation and Highway Patrol, all northbound lanes are closed in Mims in northern Brevard County after a fatal crash earlier this morning.

The FHP said the crash happened about 9 a.m. near mile marker 228 in Mims.

According to the Florida Highway Patrol, a tractor-trailer traveling north on I-95 in the outside line ran into the back of a parked CMTI truck. The CMTI truck had its arrow board and lights activated for a vehicle fire ahead.

The tractor-trailer "failed to slow or move over," the FHP email said.

The crash caused both vehicles to hit the guardrail on the shoulder.

The driver of the tractor-trailer, a 63-year-old man from Orlando was not injured and remained on the scene.

There were two people in the CMTI truck. A man in the driver's seat was pronounced dead at the scene.

A passenger, a 42-year-old man from St. Cloud, was airlifted to Lake Monroe Hospital with serious injuries, FHP said.

All northbound lanes on I-95 remained closed as of 1:45 p.m. Monday, Dec. 22.

"Motorists heading northbound on I-95 are being diverted off at S.R. 46. From there, motorists should head eastbound on S.R. 46, turn left onto northbound U.S. 1, and turn left onto westbound Deering Parkway before reaching the I-95 interchange," according to an email from FDOT.

The crash comes during the peak travel period for the Christmas season.

AAA estimated 7.5 million Floridians will be visiting family, going to vacation destinations or just getting away at least 50 miles from their homes between Dec. 20 and Jan. 1.

Contributing: C.A. Bridges, USA Today Network-Florida

This article originally appeared on Florida Today: Fatal crash closes Interstate 95 in Brevard County, Florida

title: Judge chides Ghislaine Maxwell for mentioning victim names in papers seeking to overturn conviction
description: A judge on Monday scolded Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs longtime confidant Ghislaine Maxwell for including confidential victim names in court papers seeking to set aside her 2021 sex trafficking conviction and free her from a 20-year prison sentence.  Judge Paul A. Engelmayer said exhibits included with Maxwell‚Äôs habeas petition ‚Äî which she filed on her own, without a lawyer ‚Äî will be kept under seal and out of public view ‚Äúuntil they have been reviewed and appropriately redacted to protect the identities of victims.‚Äù  Any future papers Maxwell files must be submitted under seal, the judge wrote.
fullText:
NEW YORK (AP) ‚Äî A judge on Monday scolded Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs longtime confidant Ghislaine Maxwell for including confidential victim names in court papers seeking to set aside her 2021 sex trafficking conviction and free her from a 20-year prison sentence.

Judge Paul A. Engelmayer said exhibits included with Maxwell‚Äôs habeas petition ‚Äî which she filed on her own, without a lawyer ‚Äî will be kept under seal and out of public view ‚Äúuntil they have been reviewed and appropriately redacted to protect the identities of victims.‚Äù

Any future papers Maxwell files must be submitted under seal, the judge wrote.

He said he ‚Äúreminds Maxwell, in strong terms, that she is prohibited from including in any public filings any information identifying victim(s) who were not publicly identified by name during her trial.‚Äù

A message seeking comment was left with Maxwell's lawyer, David Markus.

Maxwell filed the petition last Wednesday, two days before the Justice Department started releasing investigative records pertaining to her and Epstein in accordance with the recently enacted Epstein Files Transparency Act.

Maxwell contends that information that would have resulted in her exoneration was withheld and that false testimony was presented to the jury. She said the cumulative effect of the constitutional violations resulted in a ‚Äúcomplete miscarriage of justice.‚Äù

Engelmayer said Maxwell has until Feb. 17, 2026, to notify him whether she plans to include any information from the so-called Epstein files in her petition and must file an amended version by March 31, 2026.

A slow, heavily redacted release of files

Protecting victim identifies has been a key sticking point in the Justice Department‚Äôs ongoing release.

The department has said it plans to release records on a rolling basis by the end of the year, blaming the delay on the time-consuming process of obscuring victims‚Äô names and other identifying information. So far, the department hasn‚Äôt given any notice when new records arrive.

That approach angered some accusers and members of Congress who fought to pass the transparency act. Records that were released, including photographs, interview transcripts, call logs, court records and other documents, were either already public or heavily blacked out, and many lacked necessary context.

The Senate‚Äôs top Democrat on Monday urged colleagues to take legal action over the incremental and heavily redacted release.

Minority Leader Chuck Schumer introduced a resolution that, if passed, would direct the Senate to file or join lawsuits aimed at forcing the Justice Department to comply with the Epstein Files Transparency Act, the law enacted last month that required disclosure of records by last Friday.

‚ÄúInstead of transparency, the Trump administration released a tiny fraction of the files and blacked out massive portions of what little they provided,‚Äù Schumer, D-N.Y. said in a statement. ‚ÄúThis is a blatant cover-up.‚Äù

In lieu of Republican support, Schumer‚Äôs resolution is largely symbolic. The Senate is off until Jan. 5, more than two weeks after the deadline. Even then, it‚Äôll likely face an uphill battle for passage. But it allows Democrats to continue a pressure campaign for disclosure that Republicans had hoped to put behind them.

There were few revelations in the tens of thousands of pages of records that have been released so far. Some of the most eagerly awaited records, such as FBI victim interviews and internal memos shedding light on charging decisions, weren‚Äôt there.

Nor were there any mentions of some powerful figures who‚Äôve been in Epstein‚Äôs orbit, like Britain‚Äôs former Prince Andrew.

Some files removed, then restored

Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche on Sunday defended the Justice Department‚Äôs decision to release just a fraction of the files by the deadline as necessary to protect survivors of sexual abuse by the disgraced financier.

Blanche pledged that the Trump administration would meet its obligation required by law. But he stressed that the department was obligated to act with caution as it goes about making public thousands of documents that can include sensitive information. And he said legal precedent had long established that obligations to protect the privacy of victims permit authorities to go beyond deadlines to ensure they are protected.

Blanche, the Justice Department‚Äôs second-in-command, also defended its decision to remove several files related to the case from its public webpage, including a photograph showing Trump, less than a day after they were posted.

The missing files, which were available Friday but no longer accessible by Saturday, included images of paintings depicting nude women, and one showed a series of photographs along a credenza and in drawers. In that image, inside a drawer among other photos, was a photograph of Trump alongside Epstein, Melania Trump and Epstein‚Äôs longtime associate, Ghislaine Maxwell.

Blanche said the documents were removed because of a concern that they might also show victims of Epstein. Blanche said the Trump photo and the other documents would be reposted once redactions, if necessary, were made to protect survivors.

The Trump photograph was returned to the public webpage without alterations Sunday after it was determined that a concern by some government workers that victims may have been depicted in the picture proved unfounded, the Justice Department said.

‚ÄúWe are not redacting information around President Trump, around any other individual involved with Mr. Epstein, and that narrative, which is not based on fact at all, is completely false,‚Äù Blanche told NBC‚Äôs ‚ÄúMeet the Press.‚Äù

Blanche said Trump, a Republican, has labeled the Epstein matter ‚Äúa hoax‚Äù because ‚Äúthere‚Äôs this narrative out there that the Department of Justice is hiding and protecting information about him, which is completely false.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Epstein files existed for years and years and years and you did not hear a peep out of a single Democrat for the past four years and yet ... lo and behold, all of a sudden, out of the blue, Senator Schumer suddenly cares about the Epstein files,‚Äù Blanche said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the hoax.‚Äù

title: Legendary rock star defends his ‚Äòterrific‚Äô relationship with Trump: ‚ÄòNot everybody loves Jesus‚Äô
description: The rock icon didn't hold back when discussing political divisions.
fullText:
KISS legend Gene Simmons said his relationship with President Donald Trump is ‚Äúterrific‚Äù as he slammed Americans for caring too much about one another‚Äôs political beliefs.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt really care what people say,‚Äù Simmons said in an interview with CNN‚Äôs Manu Raju that aired Sunday. ‚ÄúLife has always been like that.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot everybody loves Jesus, but you can certainly say the following: he was a duly elected president of these United States, perhaps overwhelming by the popular vote, as well as the Electoral College. End of story,‚Äù he continued.

Simmons went on to say that it‚Äôs ‚Äúnobody‚Äôs damn business who you support.‚Äù

‚ÄúNowadays, people engage in, so, are you pro or ‚Äî and my first question is ‚ÄòWho the f--- are you? Who are you?‚Äô" Simmons said. ‚ÄúSince when does who I support or not support is the business of anyone except my conscience?‚Äù

When asked to evaluate the MAGA movement within the Republican Party, Simmons said ‚Äúsome of it makes sense and some not.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut literally, have a sense of humor,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúTake a pill, shut up and stop worrying what your next-door neighbor believes or doesn‚Äôt believe. It‚Äôs their America, too.‚Äù

Simmons, who was recognized at the Kennedy Center Honors with KISS earlier this month, joined CNN on Capitol Hill, where he is pushing for the passage of the American Music Fairness Act. The bill, which was introduced in the House in January, would require radio corporations to pay artists royalties for playing their music over AM/FM airwaves.

Simmons and music executives recently testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee in favor of the legislation. In February, hundreds in the music industry ‚Äî including Stevie Nicks, Celine Dion and Aerosmith ‚Äî called on Congress in a letter to pass the bipartisan measure to fix what they characterized as an ‚Äúinequity‚Äù that harms U.S. artists at home and abroad.

‚ÄúIf you are against this bill, you are un-American,‚Äù Simmons said during his testimony.

During the interview with CNN, Simmons responded directly to critics of the bill.

‚ÄúRadio stations last year made something like $14 billion,‚Äù he said in comments recorded on Dec. 9. ‚ÄúArtists, who you heard on the radio stations made zero. Your favorite artist, whether it‚Äôs a classic artist or a new artist, made zero. And that is inexcusable.‚Äù

title: Lowe‚Äôs worker convicted in deadly forklift attack in Maryland Home Depot parking lot
description: A Lowe‚Äôs employee accused in a deadly forklift attack in a Maryland Home Depot parking lot has been found guilty by a jury and now faces nearly 60 years in prison.
fullText:
WALDORF, Md. - A Lowe‚Äôs employee accused in a deadly forklift attack in a Maryland Home Depot parking lot has been found guilty by a jury and now faces nearly 60 years in prison.

The Charles County State‚Äôs Attorney's Office said Bryce Caleb Timothy Brown, 22, of Waldorf stole a forklift from the fenced‚Äëin rear lot of a Lowe‚Äôs on Crain Highway, where he was employed, on July 2, 2023, ramming it through the store‚Äôs rear gates and roll‚Äëup door.

Brown then drove the forklift to a nearby Home Depot on Jefferson Farm Place, where he crashed into a parked car, authorities said. Inside the vehicle was 73‚Äëyear‚Äëold Gloristine Pinkney, who had been asleep and ran from the scene. Police said Brown chased her, struck her with the forklift and ran her over, killing her.

Investigators said Brown then stole Pinkney‚Äôs vehicle, used her credit card to buy gas and traveled to Washington, D.C., and Virginia before returning home, where he was arrested later that day. Authorities do not believe the two knew each other.

Brown was convicted of second‚Äëdegree murder, theft, fourth‚Äëdegree burglary, malicious destruction of property and related charges.

He is scheduled to be sentenced Feb. 13, 2026, and faces up to 58 years in prison.

Information in this article comes from the State‚Äôs Attorney for Charles County and the Charles County Sheriff‚Äôs Office.

title: Stop Calling Me: 12 Ways to End Annoying Telemarketing Calls
description: Telemarketing calls are an unyielding annoyance of the modern world- constantly irritating you and refusing to ever stop, no matter how hard you wish they would. They‚Äôll even call on you birthday, holidays, and everything in between. Although telemarketers are only doing their job, the calls can be more than just a nuisance‚Äîthey can interrupt ‚Ä¶
fullText:
Telemarketing calls are an unyielding annoyance of the modern world- constantly irritating you and refusing to ever stop, no matter how hard you wish they would. They'll even call on you birthday, holidays, and everything in between. Although telemarketers are only doing their job, the calls can be more than just a nuisance‚Äîthey can interrupt your daily life and breach your privacy.

Telemarketing has existed since the 1950s, proving that telemarketers have perfected the art of being disruptive and persistent enough to make a sale. Ignoring them isn't always the most effective solution; you will still see and hear your phone ringing. Be kind, even as you try to filter the calls aimed at getting a sale from you; there's usually a real human on the other end of the line who's just trying to make a living.

Fortunately for you, there are several effective strategies you can take advantage of to minimize these intrusive interruptions. Here are 12 ways to get rid of pesky telemarketers and reclaim your peace of mind.

One of the simplest ways to reduce telemarketing calls is to request that they stop calling directly. When you receive a call, inform the telemarketer that you do not wish to receive further calls from their company. According to FTC regulations, legitimate telemarketing companies are required to honor such requests.

While this method may not eliminate all calls, it can significantly reduce the amount you receive from specific companies. It‚Äôs a straightforward approach that can provide immediate relief, especially from the most persistent callers.

Many telemarketers use anonymous or withheld numbers to bypass your phone's caller ID feature. By blocking anonymous callers, you can prevent them from reaching you in the first place. Most modern smartphones have built-in features or settings that allow you to block calls from unknown or private numbers.

This method is particularly effective because it stops the calls before they even ring on your end. However, some legitimate callers such as doctors or businesses might also use anonymous numbers, so weigh the pros and cons before enabling this feature.

The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) offers a National Do Not Call Registry where you can list your phone number to opt out of telemarketing calls. This free service is available to all consumers in the United States and can significantly reduce the number of unsolicited calls you receive.

To register, visit the FTC‚Äôs website and follow the instructions. Once your number is listed, it can take up to 31 days for telemarketers to register and update their records without your number.

If you are registered with the Do Not Call List and still receive telemarketing calls, it is important to report these numbers to the FTC. Reporting helps the commission track down violators and potentially take action against them.

You can file a complaint on the FTC‚Äôs website, providing details about the call and the number that contacted you. This helps protect you and aids in the broader effort to crack down on illegal telemarketing practices.

Most smartphones and phone carriers offer features that allow you to block specific numbers. You can add that number to your block list whenever you receive an unwanted call. Over time, this can build up a robust defense against repeat offenders.

While this approach requires some effort and diligence, it can effectively reduce the frequency of calls from persistent telemarketers. Remember, consistency pays off, and your block list will eventually prevent many unwanted calls.

Many phone carriers offer call screening services to help identify and block telemarketing calls before reaching you. These services often include features such as automatic spam detection, caller ID, and call blocking based on known spam databases.

Contact your carrier to learn more about the call screening options that are available to you. Incorporating these services can add an extra layer of protection, saving you time and frustration.

Numerous apps specialize in blocking spam and telemarketing calls. Apps like Truecaller use advanced algorithms and community reports to identify and block unwanted calls.

Installing one or more of these apps can provide real-time protection and updates, adapting to new telemarketing tactics and numbers as they arise. These apps often come with additional features like identifying unknown callers and managing your block list more efficiently.

When you realize you‚Äôre on the line with a telemarketer, don‚Äôt waste time engaging‚Äîsimply hang up immediately. Many telemarketers rely on your engagement to keep you on the call and potentially gather more information from you.

If you‚Äôre in a playful mood and want to have a bit of fun at the telemarketer‚Äôs expense, hand the phone over to your kids. Letting children engage with the caller can quickly discourage them from continuing the conversation.

While this may not be a conventional method, it‚Äôs a lighthearted way to deal with an otherwise frustrating situation. Plus, it can provide a few moments of amusement for both you and your children.

Another tactic is to answer the call but remain silent. Many telemarketing systems use automated dialing and rely on voice recognition to determine if someone has answered. By staying silent, you can confuse the system and cause the call to disconnect.

Over time, this method can reduce the number of calls you receive from automated systems, as they may flag your number as unresponsive. It‚Äôs a passive yet effective way to handle unwanted calls.

One proactive approach to preventing telemarketing calls is to be cautious about sharing your phone number. Only provide your number to trusted sources and consider using alternatives like email for less essential communications.

Be wary of entering your phone number on websites, online forms, or when signing up for services. Reducing the number of people and entities that have your phone number can decrease the likelihood of it ending up on telemarketers' call lists.

A virtual phone number is another strategy for keeping your primary phone number private. You can use a virtual number for online registrations, business interactions, or subscriptions, and redirect any calls to your main line or screen them separately.

Many services offer virtual phone numbers for a small fee. This way, your primary number remains private while the virtual number can handle potential telemarketing calls. If the virtual number receives too many unwanted calls, you can easily change or dispose of it without affecting your primary contact number.

title: ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre Lying Right Now‚Äô: CNN‚Äôs Scott Jennings Gets Cornered by Guest About Trump Official Who Claimed ‚ÄòNazi Streak‚Äô
description: A CNN NewsNight guest called out commentator Scott Jennings during a tense exchange about the state of the MAGA movement.
fullText:
A CNN NewsNight guest called out commentator Scott Jennings during a tense exchange about the state of the MAGA movement.

Monday‚Äôs panel discussed the aftermath of last week‚Äôs Turning Point USA event, where Ben Shapiro criticized Tucker Carlson for conducting interviews with white nationalist Nick Fuentes and for refusing to condemn Candace Owens for peddling conspiracy theories about TPUSA founder Charlie Kirk‚Äôs assassination. Owens, who previously worked for Shapiro at The Daily Wire, has claimed that the Israeli government was involved in the murder.

Carlson spoke moments later and offered a rebuttal. The next night, Steve Bannon spoke at the conference and likewise ripped Shapiro, as did Megyn Kelly. Vice President JD Vance also spoke at the event, where he told the crowd, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to apologize for being white anymore.‚Äù

On CNN NewsNight, Republican strategist Tim Parrish said there is no room for anti-Semitism and other forms og bigotry in the GOP and that Vance has adequately condemned such attacks, including his remarks about leaked Young Republican group chats that contained all manner of racial slurs and comments about Jews and ‚Äúgas chambers.‚Äù

Vance told the group chat members to ‚Äúgrow up,‚Äù but he also criticized the ‚Äúpearl clutching‚Äù by those who harshly condemned the messages and said that ‚Äúkids do stupid things.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou guys are mischaracterizing the statements that the vice president made,‚Äù Parrish said. ‚ÄúHe absolutely came out and condemned and said that there is no place for any comments like that in the Republican Party.‚Äù

Adam Mockler of MeidasTouch rejected the claim.

‚ÄúJD Vance said he‚Äôs gonna warn his kids so some ‚Äòscumbag‚Äô doesn‚Äôt leak a group chat in a similar way,‚Äù Mockler replied. ‚ÄúHe was implying the person who leaked the group chat was a scumbag. JD Vance has had the farthest thing from moral clarity this entire time.‚Äù

Mockler then pivoted to Paul Ingrassia, who was appointed by President Donald Trump to be the acting general counsel of the U.S. General Services Administration. Leaked text messages from Ingrassia show that he said he has a ‚ÄúNazi streak‚Äù and made racist remarks.

Here is Mockler‚Äôs exchange with Parrish and Jennings:

MOCKLER: And listen, do you know who Paul Ingrassia is?

MOCKLER: Do you know who Paul Ingrassia is?

JENNINGS: Yeah, we‚Äôve debated it.

MOCKLER: Do you know what‚Äì ok, so do you know what Paul Ingrassia said?

JENNINGS:¬†Yeah, we‚Äôve debated it.

MOCKLER: That he has a Nazi streak. Oh, you‚Äôve debated it. But has Trump fired him, or is he still a part of the administration?

JENNINGS: I don‚Äôt know where he is right now.

MOCKLER: He‚Äôs a part of the administration. And you know that. You‚Äôre lying right now. You know that he is a part of the administration. He is still there. And he said he has a ‚ÄúNazi streak.‚Äù So you can sit there and play coy, but you are not having the clarity that you are talking about right now. Do you condemn Paul Ingrassia?

JENNINGS: I certainly condemn anything‚Äì

MOCKLER: Should Trump fire Paul Ingrassia?

JENNINGS: ‚Äìapproximating having a Nazi streak.

Two days after Ingrassia‚Äôs texts were made public, Jennings said he agreed with the administration‚Äôs decision to withdraw Ingrassia‚Äôs nomination as head of the Office of Special Counsel. However, Trump appointed Ingrassia as acting general counsel at the General Services Administration three weeks later.

Hours before his appearance on NewsNight, Jennings said Vance will ultimately need to distance himself from conservatives who are ‚Äútrafficking in hate.‚Äù

The post ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre Lying Right Now‚Äô: CNN‚Äôs Scott Jennings Gets Cornered by Guest About Trump Official Who Claimed ‚ÄòNazi Streak‚Äô first appeared on Mediaite.

Putin‚Äôs ‚Äòdear friend‚Äô Xi piles pain on Russia‚Äôs economy
description: When Vladimir Putin made a four-day trip to visit Xi Jinping in September, he addressed his Chinese counterpart as a ‚Äúdear friend‚Äù.
fullText:
When Vladimir Putin made a four-day trip to visit Xi Jinping in September, he addressed his Chinese counterpart as a ‚Äúdear friend‚Äù.

Speaking to Xi across a vast display of orchids in Beijing‚Äôs Great Hall of the People, the Russian president claimed their ties were ‚Äúat an unprecedentedly high level‚Äù.

Certainly on the surface it appears China‚Äôs alliance with Russia has only grown stronger since Putin‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine in 2022.

Nowhere has this been more evident than when looking at trade between the two countries, which has boomed ever since the West slapped Putin with massive sanctions.

Last year, the value of trade between Russia and China hit a record $245bn (¬£182bn), fuelled by Xi becoming the world‚Äôs largest buyer of Putin‚Äôs oil and gas. Overall, China also became Russia‚Äôs biggest supplier of goods.

However, closer ties with China have come at a cost.

In particular, Russian businesses have grown increasingly frustrated at a flood of cheap Chinese goods.

Vladimir Milov, who worked in the Russian government from 1997 to 2002 before becoming a vocal Putin critic, says the economic alliance is backfiring badly for Russia.

‚ÄúIt is deeply disadvantageous,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúChina is taking advantage because it knows that Russia has nowhere to go.‚Äù

Such warnings could signal that the economic ties between the two countries are beginning to fray.

While mutual trade hit a record high in 2024, it has fallen by nearly a tenth so far this year.

One key area of tension is cars.

After Western manufacturers cut ties with Russia in 2022, Chinese competitors duly stepped in.

In the two years to 2024, Chinese car exports to Russia have increased sevenfold, prompting a growing number of complaints from domestic manufacturers.

Maxim Sokolov, the chief executive of Russian carmaker AvtoVAZ, has accused the Chinese of ‚Äúunprecedented dumping‚Äù, which he said in December has crossed ‚Äúall imaginable boundaries‚Äù.

Sales of his company‚Äôs signature Lada car have plunged, pushing the company to slash production by nearly half and move to a four-day work week at the end of September.

Russia‚Äôs largest truck manufacturer, Kamaz, also trimmed its working week in August after demand for its vehicles plunged by 60pc. At the time it blamed ‚Äúexcessive‚Äù imports.

To alleviate some of the criticism, the Kremlin has responded by significantly raising import fees on vehicles.

Since October 2024, Russia has more than doubled the ‚Äúrecycling fee‚Äù that it charges on imported cars.

This charge, which is supposedly to cover the future disposal of the vehicle but functions largely as a tariff, was 667,000 roubles (¬£6,275) per vehicle as of January this year.

This led to Chinese car exports to Russia halving in the first six months of 2025.

In July, Russian regulators also banned truck imports from a fleet of major Chinese brands ‚Äì Dongfeng, Foton, FAW and Sitrak ‚Äì which they branded a ‚Äúdirect threat‚Äù to public safety.

‚ÄúThese trade-related tensions will start to occur more and more as the market gets saturated with Chinese goods and uncompetitive Russian industries are not able to make their sales,‚Äù says John Kennedy, a research leader at Rand.

There are signs that Russia‚Äôs steel sector is also hurting.

Andrey Gartung, chief executive of the Chelyabinsk Forging and Press Plant, warned last year: ‚ÄúRussian enterprises competing with Chinese ones are holding on by the skin of their teeth.‚Äù

Not one to shy away, China has hit back with trade restrictions of its own.

Most notably, Xi reintroduced tariffs on Russian coal in January 2024, two years after the restrictions were first lifted.

This has already hit exports to China, with Milov claiming that the levies are adding to what is the worst crisis for Russia‚Äôs coal industry since the collapse of the Soviet Union.

The sector‚Äôs revenues are expected to plummet by 12pc this year alone.

Elsewhere, China has so far refused to lift a longstanding ban on imports of Russia‚Äôs largest agricultural exports ‚Äì winter wheat and barley. Instead, it buys from Ukraine and Kazakhstan.

What China does import from Russia, it gets incredibly cheaply because it has a monopoly as one of Russia‚Äôs only buyers, says Milov.

Russia‚Äôs biggest exports to China are oil and gas, which combined make up two thirds of its trade.

Igor Sechin, Rosneft‚Äôs chief executive, said that between January 2022 and June 2024, China‚Äôs savings from purchasing Russian oil compared to Middle Eastern exports amounted to as much as $18bn.

‚ÄúTaking the sanctions away, Russia is what Beijing would want every trading partner to look like,‚Äù says Gregor Sebastian, of Rhodium‚Äôs China Corporate Advisory team.

‚ÄúChina is importing raw materials that it produces into manufactured goods that it can then resell at much higher profit margins back to Russia. That is the main bulk of the relationship.‚Äù

However, more than anything, Russia wants new technology and investment from China. And it is not getting it.

The average annual flow of Chinese investment into Russia has plummeted from an average of $1.2bn from 2011 to $400m, says Milov.

In 2022, China dropped Russia from its Belt and Road financing programme, while in July, China‚Äôs commerce ministry ‚Äústrongly advised‚Äù carmakers against investing in Russia.

Many major projects that were previously announced with Chinese backing have now been scrapped or are on hold.

Russia quietly disappeared from what was supposed to be a joint development of a long-haul aircraft with the Commercial Aircraft Corporation of China.

Work had already begun on the project, initially called the CR929, which stood for ‚ÄúChina Russia‚Äù. However, the R has now been dropped, with the aircraft renamed as the C929.

Plans for Chinese CRRC Changchun Railway Vehicles to build a high-speed rail line between Moscow and Kazan in south-west Russia have also been paused.

Separately, there has been no progress on the development of the Tianjin oil refinery, a joint venture between Rosneft and the Chinese National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC), which was approved in 2014.

After the meeting between Putin and Xi in September, Gazprom announced that the two countries had signed a deal to build a ‚ÄúPower of Siberia 2‚Äù gas pipeline to China.

But while this would no doubt prove to be a huge victory for Russia, China has yet to confirm the project.

This may be a sign that, for all the pomp and ceremony, the countries‚Äô authoritarian alliance may be weaker than it appears.

‚ÄúDespite all these hugs and kisses at summits, China and Russia are very much far apart,‚Äù says Milov.

title: Calif. Equestrian Who Hired Hitman to Kill Husband Dies by Suicide Shortly After Prison Release
description: Tatyana Remley, who was convicted in a murder-for-hire plot targeting her estranged husband, died on Dec. 18, the San Diego County Medical Examiner‚Äôs Office confirmed
fullText:
Tatyana Remley was convicted in a plot to hire a hitman to kill her estranged husband, Mark Remley

Authorities said the investigation began after a suspicious house fire at the couple‚Äôs California property

Remley died on Dec. 18, 2025, from a gunshot wound to the head, the medical examiner said

A California equestrian who was convicted in a plot to have her estranged husband killed has died by suicide, the San Diego County Medical Examiner‚Äôs Office confirmed to PEOPLE.

Tatyana Remley died on Dec. 18, 2025, from a gunshot wound to the head. Her death was ruled a suicide, the medical examiner said.

Remley was convicted in a murder-for-hire case involving her estranged husband, Mark Remley. NBC San Diego reported in December 2023 that Remley pleaded guilty to solicitation to commit murder and was sentenced to three years and eight months in state prison.

PEOPLE previously reported that she was arrested in 2023 after allegedly meeting with an undercover officer and offering to pay for her estranged husband‚Äôs killing.

The investigation began after a house fire at the couple‚Äôs ranch property in Del Mar, an unincorporated area of San Diego County north of the city, according to the San Diego County Sheriff‚Äôs Department.

Deputies said an arson unit was called to the scene and that Remley was initially arrested that day for alleged firearms-related offenses after officers said they found three firearms and ammunition in her possession.

The following day, the sheriff‚Äôs department said investigators opened a murder-for-hire investigation after receiving information that Remley was attempting to hire someone to kill her estranged husband.

‚ÄúShe provided detailed information on how she wanted her husband killed and his body disposed of,‚Äù the sheriff‚Äôs department alleged in a statement. Authorities also claimed that Remley brought firearms and U.S. currency as a down payment for the killing.

According to The Coast News, Mark Remley told the outlet that his wife had offered a mutual friend $2 million to kill him. The friend declined and alerted police, prompting a sting operation, the outlet reported. Remley later met with an undercover officer at a local Starbucks, according to The Coast News.

In divorce papers, Remley said she and a friend were present at the property at the time of the fire but claimed she did not know how it started, The Coast News reported. Her husband, however, told the outlet that he believed the fire was intentionally set after he allegedly discovered she was trying to have him killed.

The Remleys married in 2011, then separated and reconciled multiple times over the years, according to The Coast News.

Remley was charged with arson in connection with the house fire and was arraigned on Sept. 11, per a criminal complaint shared with PEOPLE by the San Diego County District Attorney's Office. She was scheduled to return to court on March 3, 2026, per the office.

PEOPLE was unable to reach an attorney for Remley or her estranged husband for comment at press time.

title: Argument over flat tire leads to stabbing in Grapevine store parking lot, police say
description: An argument over a flat tire between two friends escalated into a stabbing early Sunday morning in the parking lot of a Grapevine furniture store, according to police.
fullText:
An argument between two friends over a flat tire turned into a physical altercation in a Grapevine furniture store parking lot, resulting in the driver stabbing his passenger in the ribcage.

The driver, identified as Shawn Michael Scott, was arrested at the scene and charged with aggravated assault, a second-degree felony.

The victim was transported to a local hospital where he is being treated for non-life-threatening injuries.

GRAPEVINE, Texas - An argument over a flat tire between two friends escalated into a stabbing early Sunday morning in the parking lot of a Grapevine furniture store, according to police.

Officers responded to a stabbing call at the Ashley HomeStore on Grapevine Mills Parkway around 4 a.m. Sunday. Investigators determined that two men, who were reportedly friends, pulled into the parking lot after the driver struck a curb and blew out a tire.

A verbal argument over the situation turned physical. During the fight, police say the driver, Shawn Michael Scott, produced a knife and stabbed his friend in the ribcage.

The victim was transported to a local hospital with non-life-threatening injuries.

Scott was arrested at the scene and faces a second-degree felony charge of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon.

Authorities have not released further details regarding the specific nature of the argument or the duration of the men's friendship.

Information in this article comes from Grapevine police.

title: De Smet boys, Lennox girls pick up Monday wins
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D. (KELO) ‚Äî The fourth-ranked De Smet boys basketball team claimed a 59-48 win at No. 2 Dell Rapids St. Mary‚Äôs, and the second-ranked Lennox girls basketball dominated Canton 55-26 Monday night.
fullText:
SIOUX FALLS, S.D. (KELO) ‚Äî The fourth-ranked De Smet boys basketball team claimed a 59-48 win at No. 2 Dell Rapids St. Mary‚Äôs, and the second-ranked Lennox girls basketball dominated Canton 55-26 Monday night.

In the boys game, the Cardinals scored eight of the first nine points and led 13-7 after one quarter. The Bulldogs responded by outscoring them 20-6 in the second to take an eight-point lead into the locker room.

The girls game was dominated by the Orioles as they outscored the C-Hawks 37-13 in the first half.

title: Business expert: Chiefs move could energize Kansas sports identity
description: Even though Wichita will be a few hours away from the new field, the hope is the team's presence can strengthen the area's sports identity.
fullText:
WICHITA, Kan. (KSNW) ‚Äì Being a Kansas City Chiefs fan is often about loyalty and emotional commitment. But with the Chiefs announcing Monday that they would leave the historic Arrowhead Stadium in Missouri and move into a not-yet-built $3 billion stadium on the Kansas side of Kansas City, Kansas-based fans soon won‚Äôt need to root for their team across state lines.

‚ÄúThat creates energy that I don‚Äôt think we really understand or really appreciate until it starts happening, until the stadium gets built, they play their first game, they play their first season,‚Äù Kevin Jenks, the president and CEO of the Wichita Sports Commission, said.

The Chiefs spent more than five decades playing at Arrowhead. They intend to build their new stadium in Wyandotte County, in the same area as Kansas Speedway and the Legends retail district.

‚ÄòI just love Arrowhead‚Äô: Some Chiefs super fans not sold on move to Kansas

Even though Wichita will be a few hours away from the new field, the hope is that the team‚Äôs presence can strengthen the area‚Äôs sports identity. Wichita Sports Commission hopes that includes strengthening ongoing partnerships with the franchise.

‚ÄúThe Chiefs have been big proponents of getting flag football into high schools, and we were a part of that locally with some Wichita schools,‚Äù Jenks said. ‚ÄúWe are still continuing to promote and be a part of that process.‚Äù

Dr. Larry Straub, an associate professor of business management at Newman University, says the Chiefs‚Äô presence is likely to improve Kansas‚Äô national image. However, he‚Äôs skeptical that the financial boom that comes with a major sports team moving in will echo around the state.

‚ÄúFrom an economics standpoint, I think the closer you are to Kansas City, the more benefits you‚Äôre going to have,‚Äù Straub said.

title: Pep Guardiola was far from happy with how Manchester City played against West Ham
description: On the surface, Manchester City picked up a routine 3-nil win over West Ham at the Etihad last Saturday. In the first half of Saturday‚Äôs match, City dominated the game and didn‚Äôt allow West Ham to...
fullText:
On the surface, Manchester City picked up a routine 3-nil win over West Ham at the Etihad last Saturday. In the first half of Saturday‚Äôs match, City dominated the game and didn‚Äôt allow West Ham to have a single shot on goal. In the second-half, West Ham had their moments, although it must be said that City never really felt like they got out of second gear. Any 3-nil win in the Premier League will be gleefully accepted. Speaking after his team‚Äôs win over West Ham, Pep Guardiola was far from pleased with his team‚Äôs display. Pep Guardiola‚Äôs comments are on the money as there is so much more to come from City this season.

It was clear after Manchester City‚Äôs win that Pep Guardiola was far from pleased with his team‚Äôs performance against West Ham. Although Manchester City took a 2-nil lead into halftime, his team had dominated West Ham and really should have been out of sight by halftime. But while City were comfortable in, and dominated, possession in the first half, they didn‚Äôt really create a host of chances after Erling Haaland‚Äôs 5th-minute goal. City played in first or second gear and didn‚Äôt press for another goal. This wasn‚Äôt lost on Pep Guardiola as explained to Sky Sports post-match: ‚ÄúWith the ball, we are not good. So we give away many things because we are not in the right spots to break the lines and make the next steps.‚Äù

‚ÄúBecause the players are not courageous to do that action. But we will improve it because we are so open. The group is amazing, we will try to do it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy, I cannot deny, but the way we play with the ball we have to improve or it will not be enough in March or April to be a contender to win the league.‚Äù

‚ÄúI said to my players: ‚ÄòMerry Christmas for everyone but it will not be enough if we do not improve.‚Äù

‚ÄúWith the positions we have to be brave. We were not there. How many chances did they have first half? Zero, none. But even with that we were not in the right places to create, to be more solid. We didn‚Äôt do the right process to be more consistent. Gigi [Donnarumma] saved us.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf they follow me we will be there, but we have to improve. I know the level in this league, I know Arsenal, I know how tough they are. It‚Äôs not enough. The spirit is there. But many, many things we must do better.‚Äù

It is easy to see that Pep Guardiola is playing for keeps this season. The Manchester City manager wants his team to challenge for this season‚Äôs Premier League title and perhaps more. He also wants to see his team improve. That seems a ridiculous notion to dig into after a 3-nil win but Pep Guardiola‚Äôs point does stand up. Playing consistently like they did against West Ham will likely see City fall short of their goal of winning the Premier League title this season. So improvement is needed from Pep Guardiola‚Äôs side. Premier League tickets can be found at the following link to see if Pep Guardiola‚Äôs call for his players to improve comes to life in the coming weeks.

It is easy to see what annoyed Pep Guardiola on Saturday. West Ham offered nothing during the first half of Saturday‚Äôs match. Nuno Espirito Santo‚Äôs side barely offered a threat. But the City players sat back and didn‚Äôt seize the initiative after scoring an early goal. They were possibly lulled into a false sense of security. The City players weren‚Äôt brave enough in possession in the first half and didn‚Äôt have the movement Pep Guardiola demands of his team to put West Ham away after taking an early lead. It would seem that is what set Pep Guardiola off after his team‚Äôs win and it will be interesting to see if this City side goes up a gear after Christmas.

Pep Guardiola has spelt out what he wasn‚Äôt happy with after his team‚Äôs win¬† over West Ham. Manchester City‚Äôs possession and positional play has to improve to see this City side go up a gear. You do sense that the improvement is coming, but Pep Guardiola wants to see it in Manchester City‚Äôs next Premier League fixture against Nottingham Forest at The City Ground on December 27.

title: SDSU relishes chances to host nationally-ranked foes
description: BROOKINGS, S.D. (KELO) ‚Äî Sunday marked the 19th time the South Dakota State women‚Äôs basketball team hosted a nationally-ranked team in the program‚Äôs Division-I era, and No. 2 Texas was the highest-ranked foe to ever make the trip to Brookings. SDSU ultimately fell to the Longhorns 70-51 inside First Bank & Trust Arena, but the [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
BROOKINGS, S.D. (KELO) ‚Äî Sunday marked the 19th time the South Dakota State women‚Äôs basketball team hosted a nationally-ranked team in the program‚Äôs Division-I era, and No. 2 Texas was the highest-ranked foe to ever make the trip to Brookings.

SDSU ultimately fell to the Longhorns 70-51 inside First Bank & Trust Arena, but the Jackrabbits view the experience of playing a Final Four participant from a season ago worthwhile. This year is the fourth straight season the Jacks hosted a ranked team.

‚ÄúIt was just a great opportunity in a lot of ways,‚Äù SDSU head coach Aaron Johnston said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll continue to find chances to play these teams and try and bring them here. We had a great crowd and everybody was into it. It just really I think showed well for where we‚Äôre at as a program. But it is hard to play against national championship caliber teams. And that‚Äôs really what Texas is.‚Äù

‚ÄúPlanning teams like that make us all better,‚Äù SDSU senior forward Brooklyn Meyer said. ‚ÄúObviously they‚Äôre long, they‚Äôre athletic. It‚Äôs good to run our offense and run our plays and stuff like that against a team like that. And so I feel like today was a really good day for growth as a team.‚Äù

Texas, now 14-0 this season, saw SDSU as strong preparation for their tough conference slate in the SEC.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good for us,‚Äù Texas head coach Vic Schaefer said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good for us in getting us ready for the SEC. But it‚Äôs also good for the game to grow, the game for our kids to come up here and play in this environment. It‚Äôll help us in the SEC, no doubt about it.‚Äù

SDSU is now 9-10 in games against ranked teams in Brookings, but the team will continue to seek these opportunities.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll continue to move in that direction because I think it helps build our program,‚Äù Johnston said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs just absolutely no downside to playing great competition. We‚Äôre willing to stretch ourselves. And we‚Äôve learned and grow and learn from it. I think our fans appreciate it. I think our team enjoys it, and we‚Äôll try and keep doing it.‚Äù

The 10-4 Jackrabbits are set to open Summit League play on New Year‚Äôs Day against St. Thomas in Brookings.

title: After USC ran away scared, Notre Dame soaks up the glory of BYU on the schedule
description: Notre Dame adds BYU to its football schedule for 2026 and 2027, and it‚Äôs a win for both programs.
fullText:
It‚Äôs funny how funny things can be ‚Äî even at the expense of yourself. Let‚Äôs run this timeline past you for a quick second:

Notre Dame and BYU were both left out of the college football playoff for different reasons ‚Äî and both had a case against the committee.

ESPN thought they scored a major win with a Notre Dame VS BYU Pop Tarts Bowl matchup.

Notre Dame showed that they had a little more self-respect than others by telling ESPN to take a hike (turning the other cheek is null and void in football).

BYU cries and runs to social media to look for validation like they were a cast member on Secret Lives of Mormon Wives and send out the Mom Talk army.

USC has been sitting there sad that they suck so bad, and thinking that since they can‚Äôt ever beat Notre Dame ‚Äî they need to end things.

Notre Dame announces a home and home against BYU in 2026 and 2027.

Notre Dame Football Announces Series with BYU

SOUTH BEND, Ind.¬†‚Äì The University of Notre Dame football team has announced that Notre Dame and Brigham Young University will play at Edwards Stadium in Provo, Utah in 2026, and at Notre Dame Stadium in 2027 in a home-and-home series. Specific dates and broadcast information will be announced at a later date.

The two programs have met on nine previous occasions as the Irish lead the all-time series 7-2. The series is tied at one win apiece in Provo while Notre Dame has a 5-1 advantage at home against BYU. Most recently, the Irish took a 28-20 win over the No. 16 ranked Cougars in the 2022 Shamrock Series contest at Allegiant Stadium in Las Vegas.

The Irish have been ranked on five occasions while the Cougars have been ranked once in the all-time matchups between the two teams. The teams first faced off against one another on October 24, 1992 at Notre Dame Stadium as the No. 10 Irish prevailed 42-16. Notre Dame‚Äôs first trip to Provo came on October 16, 1993 and saw the No. 3 ranked Irish win 45-20.

Notre Dame is 29-9-1 against current Big 12 teams all-time. The Irish have faced BYU more than any other current Big 12 member in the history of Notre Dame football.

Them: We‚Äôre dOne sCHedulinG GOod nOn-COnfEREnce GaMes

Us: Spot the ball https://t.co/nNhwvLGPD6

‚Äî BYU Cougars (@BYUCougars) December 22, 2025

I don‚Äôt mind BYU soaking up the glory of NOT being cowards. They have a sense of bravado that probably rivals their namesake (look it up) and to be honest‚Ä¶ they need this game. It wasn‚Äôt the two losses to Texas Tech that kept BYU out of the playoff at 11-2 ‚Äî it was the weak Big 12 conference combined with an out of conference schedule that included Portland State, East Carolina, and Stanford.

So don‚Äôt get it twisted. BYU Needs this game and they are more than happy to schedule it ‚Äî especially one in Provo which they were promised a long time ago. So long ago that legend tells us that some BYU kids look at it as their birthright.

As much as I am disappointed in the demise of the USC rivalry, this game looks like it could be a lot of fun over the next two years. Maybe it will become a more regular game on the schedule, and maybe it won‚Äôt, but for right now I‚Äôm going to soak it up.

title: Philip Rivers family tree: Meet 10 kids, grandkid, wife Tiffany and more from Alabama roots
description: Here's a full guide to the family of longtime NFL quarterback Philip Rivers.
fullText:
Philip Rivers family tree: Meet 10 kids, grandkid, wife Tiffany and more from Alabama roots originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Philip Rivers wife: Tiffany Rivers

Philip Rivers dad: Steve Rivers

One of the longtime quarterbacks to emerge from the 2000s in the NFL, Philip Rivers certainly lived up to his first-round price tag in the 2004 Draft.

A member of the Los Angeles Chargers franchise for over a decade, including some time in San Diego, Rivers later spent time with the Indianapolis Colts.

The gunslinger can be found all over NFL all-time passing leaderboards, a durable quarterback who consistently put up solid numbers on an annual basis. Rivers is also well-known for his large family with his wife, Tiffany.

Here's what to know about Philip Rivers' family.

MORE: Breaking down Philip Rivers' Hall of Fame case

Philip Rivers has 10 kids ‚Äî seven daughters and three sons ‚Äî with his wife, Tiffany Rivers. When the youngest child,¬†Andrew Joseph Rivers, was born in November 2023, the oldest Rivers child, Halle Rivers, was 21 years old.

MORE: Full Joe Flacco teams timeline

Yes, Philip Rivers is, in fact, a grandfather. His oldest daughter, who was born in 2002 ‚Äî before he was drafted into the NFL in 2004‚Äî has a child.

MORE: What is Justin Herbert's net worth?

Here's what to know about the 10 children of Philip Rivers.

Of Philip Rivers' 10 children, three are sons. The oldest of the bunch is Gunner Rivers, who was born in 2008. Gunner goes by his middle name ‚Äî his first name is also Philip, like his dad.

"It's kind of crazy because we're wearing his jersey and sometimes people say 'Hi, Philip Rivers,' because I am wearing the jersey," Gunner said in 2019, per People. "But they don't actually know that I'm actually Philip Rivers!¬†Gunner is my middle name."

Gunner Rivers was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes when he was five years old. His mother, Tiffany, told People in 2019 that she recalled Gunner "starting to get really weak and tired," and his diagnosis was confirmed through a blood test. Since then, the family has helped him manage the condition.

‚ÄúWhat we‚Äôve learned through our experience is that these kids are warriors,‚Äù Philip Rivers told PEOPLE. ‚ÄúWe have seen firsthand the tremendous responsibility it is for these children to have the discipline to manage the disease with the support of family, and their health providers to live their best lives.‚Äù

Philip and Tiffany sold custom products through Tiffany's swimwear brand,¬†Hermoza, to raise money for diabetes foundations in 2019.

Like his father, Gunner became the starting quarterback at his high school,¬†St. Michael Catholic in Alabama, as a freshman. Philip has coached the team led by his son, saying in 2023 that he doesn't have a desire to coach any higher than high school.

‚ÄúI think I would have gone right into it had that been what I wanted to do,‚Äù Philip Rivers told AL.com. ‚ÄúBut, really, I‚Äôve longed to coach my boys and these other 15-18 year-old boys since I was 25. I‚Äôm good right here.‚Äù

Per AL.com, with Gunner as his starting quarterback, Philip Rivers led¬†St. Michael Catholic to the playoffs in 2023 for the first time in school history. As of 2025, Gunner was a junior and beginning to eye college recruiting, with Philip Rivers telling AL.com that the family was keeping up with college football more because of it.

247Sports has rated Gunner as a four-star quarterback prospect in the class of 2027, listing offers from Auburn, Miami, Boston College and more. And naturally, 247Sports scouting director Andrew Ivins compared Gunner's play style to his father's.

"Modern pocket passer with elite pedigree that wins with touch, timing and sound decision-making. Owns more of a unique shot put-like release, but makes it work, much like dad did many moons ago," Ivins wrote of Gunner Rivers. "Projects at this stage as a high-end distributor with a rare set of intangibles that has a chance to be a difference-maker at the game‚Äôs highest level."

As for Peter Rivers, born in 2011, his father described him as an "old soul" to the Indianapolis Star in 2020. Peter also loves sports, his father said.

‚ÄúHe kind of reminds me of a little slot receiver,‚Äù Philip Rivers said of Peter, per IndyStar. ‚ÄúKind of like a Wes Welker.‚Äù

The youngest son is Andrew, who was born in October 2023. He was the Rivers' 10th child.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs awesome. Tiffany is awesome,‚Äù Philip Rivers¬†told AL.com when Andrew was born. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter if it‚Äôs the first child or the 10th child. It‚Äôs an awesome miracle every time. Everyone is home now, and everyone is good.‚Äù

Philip and Tiffany Rivers have seven daughters. The oldest is Halle, who was born in July 2002 ‚Äî around two years before Philip reached the NFL, while he still was playing football at NC State. Tiffany also went to NC State.

Per People, Halle previously said that she's used to the public interest that comes with having a quarterback father.

"He's been famous since before I was born," Halle said, per People. "It's just been normal kind of my whole life. ...¬†He's an NFL quarterback; he's doing a million different things every day, but every day he comes home, and he wants to be with us. If he has one extra minute that he could do something else, he'll be with us."

In 2020, Philip Rivers told the Indianapolis Star that Halle reminds him of his wife.

‚ÄúShe reminds me, big-time, of her mom, which is a big compliment,‚Äù Rivers said, per the Indianapolis Star. ‚ÄúThe biggest compliment I can probably give.‚Äù

As of 2025, Halle Rivers has a child of her own, making Philip and Tiffany grandparents. Philip announced in May 2025 that he had a new grandson.

Caroline Rivers was the couple's second child, born in 2005, when Philip was beginning his Chargers career.

‚ÄúCaroline is very strong-willed, and I say that as a huge compliment,‚Äù Rivers said of Caroline in 2020. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs kind of a go-getter in that regard.‚Äù

Grace Rivers, born in 2006, was nicknamed "Combo" by her parents at a young age, per the Indianapolis Star, for¬†being like a blend of her mother and her father. She played both tennis and basketball.

‚ÄúShe goes with the flow,‚Äù Philip Rivers said of Grace.

Born in 2010, Sarah Rivers was the couple's fourth daughter. Philip said in 2020 that Grace had gotten into swimming as she tried to find a sport she enjoyed.

‚ÄúSarah‚Äôs got a big personality, loves to talk,‚Äù Philip Rivers said. ‚ÄúShe is chatty, and I say that in a good way.‚Äù

In 2013, Philip and Tiffany welcomed their seventh child, Rebecca Rivers, and in 2015, Clare Rivers was their eighth child. Philip called Rebecca "strong-willed" to the Indianapolis Star in 2020; he also shared that Clare was born exactly two years after Rebecca, so they share a birthday.

‚ÄúThey use the term they‚Äôre 'birthday sisters',‚Äù Philip Rivers said. ‚ÄúThey enjoy having the same birthday right now. I don‚Äôt know if it will be the same when they‚Äôre 12 or 14.‚Äù

Anna Rivers is the couple's youngest daughter. She was born in March 2019, with the Chargers' social media accounts announcing her birth.

SHE'S HERE.

Welcome to the world, Anna Rivers üë∂ https://t.co/oafdNNI6lI

‚Äî Los Angeles Chargers (@chargers) March 26, 2019

Before Anna was born,¬†Tiffany told WWD¬†that the arrival of their seventh daughter would be a generational experience for the Rivers family.

‚ÄúThis is the third generation in Philip‚Äôs family, who has seven girls and two boys so we were pretty excited about that," she said. "When we told his 91-year-old grandfather, he said, ‚ÄòYou didn‚Äôt have to go to the doctor to find that out. I could have told you ‚Äî that‚Äôs family history.‚Äô ‚Äù

Philip Rivers has one known grandson, as his oldest daughter, Halle, welcomed a son. In a video shared by Jon Gruden in May 2025, Philip shared that he had become a grandfather.

MORE:Meet Justin Herbert's full family

Philip Rivers' wife is Tiffany Rivers. The two met in middle school in Alabama, then began dating in high school before attending North Carolina State University together then getting married in 2001 during their freshman year of college. Since then, Philip and Tiffany have welcomed 10 children.

Philip told¬†The Chastity Project¬†that he remembered first seeing Tiffany when he was young.

‚ÄúWith Tiffany, I remember pointing her out at a ballgame at the ball field when I was young,‚Äù he said.¬†‚ÄúBut I remember telling my mom, ‚ÄòHey Mom, see that girl over there, she‚Äôs a good girl.‚Äô And she was centered on faith and Christ. She had those values that I was looking for.‚Äù

Philip also said that while he grew up in¬†the Catholic Church, his wife converted and became a Catholic the day before their wedding.

‚ÄúMy wife had a lot to do with it, she‚Äôs a convert and she actually became Catholic the day before we got married," Philip told Life Teen, per¬†The Christian Post. "There‚Äôs so many gifts from the Faith to appreciate and it strikes people differently, but the one-ness of the Church wherever you are, Raleigh, San Diego, Alabama. Every place we were was home because the Catholic Church is the same everywhere."

Philip and Tiffany welcomed their first daughter, Halle, while they were in school at NC State in 2002. Philip was the starting quarterback for the Wolfpack, while Tiffany "had a job working with children," per People.

In 2019, Philip spoke about how "steady" Tiffany has been as a mother and wife for their family.

""Our family wouldn't be what it is without her.¬†She provides a great steadiness for all of us," he said. "She's great for me also from a football standpoint as far as balancing my energy and passion I have for football.¬†And she's the same with our family."

Through all the ups and downs that comes with football, and all the commitments that I obviously have, I can't imagine doing this without her.¬†There's¬†no way¬†I could do it without her."

Tiffany co-founded a swimwear line called¬†Hermoza¬†alongside Marisa De Lecce. She also worked with Philip in 2009 to¬†create the¬†Rivers of Hope Foundation, which¬†helped orphaned and foster children find homes.¬†The nonprofit raised over $1 million until its closure in 2013.

"Tiffany and I are honored to be involved in bringing hope and awareness to the plight of foster children in San Diego County. But now we want to broaden our focus and take a behind-the-scenes approach to helping children," Philip said in a statement at the time,¬†per CBS 8. "Tiffany and I have seen great things happen in the last four years with the public foundation, and now we want to expand our personal efforts for these purposes. It takes us out of the public eye and puts the kids center-stage.‚Äù

MORE:¬†Anthony Richardson's full family tree

In December 2025, when Rivers was playing his second game since un-retiring for the Colts, his entire family was in attendance to watch him take on the San Francisco 49ers. Rivers was seen relishing the moment, waving up to his family from the field.

Philip Rivers family is in the house watching their Dad on MNF pic.twitter.com/X3i0YpJdEu

‚Äî 49ers & NFL News 24/7 (@49ersSportsTalk) December 23, 2025

Gang's all here üíô pic.twitter.com/z16NYmqjbO

‚Äî The Sporting News (@sportingnews) December 23, 2025

Here's a photo of a majority of the Rivers family, with the parents and eight of their children, before Anna and Andrew were born.

MORE:Complete list of Super Bowl MVP winners through the years

Philip Rivers' dad is Steve Rivers, who also played football and is a former high school football coach.¬†Steve played linebacker at¬†Mississippi State¬†in the 1970s.

According to AL.com, Steve retired from coaching in 2006 as the winner of¬†188 games in 25 years, including 125 in Alabama. He coached at Pelham for two years, Decatur for 15 and Athens High for four years. At Athens High, he coached Philip before he became a college and NFL star.

Steve also coached in North Carolina¬†at Wakefield High. As of 2020, Steve and his wife, Joan, lived in¬†Decatur, where he used to coach, per AL.com.

Philip wound up following in his father's footsteps by coaching his own son, Gunner, in high school football.

"He told me he wanted to coach his sons, Gunner and Pete. He‚Äôll tell you today some of the best times he ever had were playing for Athens High," Steve told AL.com of Philip coaching. He loved playing high school football and being part of a team that I was coaching. He always looked forward to playing for me. He has been around it his whole life. He longed for the day when he could play and now he is looking forward to the day when he is coaching, but he‚Äôs also focused on the Colts.‚Äù

MORE:Looking back at the oldest players ever selected in the NFL Draft

Philip Rivers' mother's name is Joan Rivers ‚Äî but not the famous late comedian, who is from New York.

MORE:Ranking the best QBs taken with picks 1-32, from Peyton Manning to Lamar Jackson

Rivers' mother, Joan Rivers, is a school teacher from Alabama. She taught at St. Ann Catholic School in Decatur, Alabama, teaching math and religion.¬†Steve also coached football in Decatur.

Philip Rivers said in 2014 that he got his competitive spirit from his mother.

"I think my dad‚Äôs side (athletic) but my mom needs credit for a lot of the competitiveness," he said. "Everybody thinks my dad was a football coach and all the competitive juices came from my dad, but my mom doesn‚Äôt play anything unless we‚Äôre keeping score."

Joan Rivers said in 2019 that she prayed a lot watching Philip play football.

"Sometimes I pray about things that I don't know if it's OK to pray about, like, 'Is it OK to pray that he never throws another interception in this game?'" she said, per ESPN. "It's been fun, and it's going to be so bittersweet when it's over because you can relax a little bit, but I know how much he loves the game, and we all do.

"But I do pray a lot during the game because I've just seen so many injuries and we haven't got time for injuries. We need Philip upright. Other than that, I'm real nervous during the game because I want him to win so bad, and I am competitive. I'm just so pleased with everything that has happened in his life. He's just been such a good role model for his brother and sister, and for even us. He's such a good leader. He leads our family, in a way. And I think people like for someone to get out there and say, 'Let's go.'"

MORE:Carson Wentz teams timeline, from Colts to Vikings

Philip Rivers is 44 years old. He will turn 45 on Dec. 8, 2026.

MORE:Most Super Bowl wins in history by player

According to Celebrity Net Worth, Philip Rivers has a net worth of $100 million.

He made¬†$242,150,000 in his NFL career, per Over the Cap.

MORE:How does NFL MVP voting work?

Rivers was born in¬†Decatur, Alabama, which is where his father was a high school football coach and his mother was a teacher.

Rivers played high school football at¬†Athens High School under his father, who was his coach.
